sentences: Elaine Noble (born January 22, 1944) is an American politician and LGBT activist who served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for two terms starting in January 1975.
section: N/A

sentences: She was the first openly lesbian or gay candidate elected to a state legislature.
section: N/A

sentences: She served two terms as representative for the Fenway-Kenmore and Back Bay neighborhoods of Boston.
section: N/A
== Early life and education ==

sentences: Early life and education
section: == Early life and education ==
== Early life and education ==

sentences: Elaine Noble was born in New Kensington, Pennsylvania on January 22, 1944.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Noble gained her B.F. A degree from Boston University in 1966, an S.M. in speech and education at Emerson College in 1970, and an M. Ed.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: at Harvard University in 1974.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: After graduation, she worked at a job-year women's school where she came out as a lesbian.
section: == Early life and education ==
== Activism ==

sentences: Activism ==
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Before entering politics, Noble worked as a speech instructor and an advertising manager.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: She was involved in LGBT rights activism in Boston.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Noble helped organize Boston's early Pride marches.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: With Ann Murray, she formed the Massachusetts Women's Political Caucus, and served on the Governor's Commission on the Status of Women.
section: == Activism ==
== Political career ==

sentences: Political career ==
section: == Political career ==
== Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: Massachusetts House of Representatives ===
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: In 1974, Noble was elected to the state House of Representatives for the 6th Suffolk district with 59% of the vote.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She has described the campaign as "very ugly," including "shooting through my windows, destroying my car, breaking windows at my campaign headquarters, [and] serious harassment."
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: Her election made her the first openly LGBT candidate elected to a state-level office in the United States.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She was sworn into office on New Year's Day 1975 by governor Michael Dukakis.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: As an educator, Noble supported desegregation of Boston public schools.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She encouraged her campaigners to oversee school pick-ups and drop-offs for children in her district.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She was the only white member of the Boston delegation that rode school busses with the children.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: Her support angered her constituents, both conservative as well as gay and lesbian, who expected her to focus solely on gay and lesbian issues.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: Her house was vandalized and she was threatened with a gun.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She also felt burdened and frustrated by the demands of gay men and lesbians who seemed to expect that she speak for all of them.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She said, "The gay community expected me to be on call 24 hours a day.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: It was like they felt they owned me.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: "Noble was an early critic of Father Paul Shanley, a Catholic priest who was ultimately convicted of sex crimes in 2005.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: She reported Shanley's comments and behavior to Boston officials on several occasions in the 1970s to no avail.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: Noble was re-elected in 1976 with almost 90% of the vote, and her second two-year term started on January 1, 1977.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===

sentences: In March 1977, Noble was part of the first delegation of gay men and lesbians invited to the White House under President Jimmy Carter to discuss issues important to the LGBT community.
section: == Political career == | === Massachusetts House of Representatives ===
== Political career == | === 1978 United States Senate campaign ===

sentences: United States Senate campaign ===
section: == Political career == | === 1978 United States Senate campaign ===

sentences: After two terms in the Massachusetts House, Noble ran for the United States Senate in 1978.
section: == Political career == | === 1978 United States Senate campaign ===

sentences: She finished last out of five Democrats who competed in the primary, with 52,464 votes (5.8%).
section: == Political career == | === 1978 United States Senate campaign ===

sentences: She did not run for re-election to the House.
section: == Political career == | === 1978 United States Senate campaign ===
== Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: Later work in politics =
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===
== Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: She later went to work for Mayor of Boston Kevin White.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: Noble was required to testify in front of a grand jury for nineteen hours in connection with an FBI investigation into bribery in the mayor's office.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: No charges were brought against Noble.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: After leaving Mayor White's office, Noble established Noble Consulting, a healthcare consulting group.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: In 1986, Noble and Ellen Ratner formed a LGBT alcohol and drug treatment center in Minneapolis called the Pride Institute.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: She attempted to establish a similar center in Massachusetts, but was rebuffed by local government.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: Noble ran unsuccessfully for the Cambridge, Massachusetts city council in 1991 and 1993.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: In her 1991 campaign, she expressed support for rent control policies, a domestic partnership ordinance, and direct election of the city's mayor.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: Noble also ran on fiscal responsibility at the city-level, offering ideas for cutting spending without raising taxes or cutting funding to essential services.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===

sentences: Despite some policy differences, including on abortion, Noble endorsed Francis X. Bellotti as Democratic candidate in the 1990 Massachusetts gubernatorial race.
section: == Political career == | === Later work in politics ===
== Retirement from public life ==

sentences: Retirement from public life ==
section: == Retirement from public life ==

sentences: In 1994, Noble took work as head administrator at Middlesex County Hospital but resigned after six months.
section: == Retirement from public life ==

sentences: In 2009, she made a rare fundraising appearance at a Stonewall gala benefiting Compass Community Center in Lake Worth, Florida.
section: == Retirement from public life ==
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Noble had a relationship with writer Rita Mae Brown in the 1970s and has since retained privacy regarding her personal life.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: She lives in Florida.
section: == Personal life ==
== Tributes ==

sentences: Tributes ==
section: == Tributes ==

sentences: In 2015, she was named by Equality Forum as one of their 31 Icons of the 2015 LGBT History Month.
section: == Tributes ==
